citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Actinomycetospora chlora sp. nov.
Actinomycetospora chlora [chlo′ra. N.L. fem. adj. chlora (from Gr. adj. khloros -a -on) greenish-yellow, referring to the greenish-yellow to pale green colour on yeast extract-starch medium].
The surface of the colonies is powdery.
The colour of the substrate mycelium is pale greenish yellow to vivid yellow.
Spore chains are white and the spore surface is smooth.
The substrate mycelium is long, well-developed and branched.
Grows at 15–28 °C, pH 5.0–8.0 and NaCl concentrations up to 1 %.
l-Arabinose, d-arabitol, d-fructose, glycerol, d-ribose, sucrose and turanose are utilized as sole carbon sources.

Positive for gelatin hydrolysis, acid phosphatase, esterase lipase (C-8), α-glucosidase, leucine aminopeptidase, pyrazinamidase, pyrrolidonyl arylamidase and valine aminopeptidase, but negative for aesculin hydrolysis, urea hydrolysis and nitrate reduction.
The major cellular fatty acids are iso-C16 : 0 and C16 : 1 cis-9.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 73 mol%.
The type strain is TT07I-57T ( = NBRC 105900T = KACC 14252T), which was isolated from a paddy soil on Iriomote Island, Okinawa, Japan.
